probability of B given A:  p( B | A ) = p( A | B ) *  p(B)  / p(A)

fun datasets to play with...

Register for an API key at http://developer.nytimes.com/apps/register and select "Article Search API"
python nytimes_pull.py  -> creates two files "arts" and "sports"
python classify.py     -> prints probabilities
nltk has a really nice sentence tokenizer (seems like it would be an easy problem for English, but becomes tough when the sentence has Dr. or Mrs. or 3.5)
Porter Stemming Algorithm:  M.F. Porter, 1980, http://tartarus.org/~martin/PorterStemmer/def.txt
WordNet has synonyms which helps expand your set of "features" for a data set

>>> word_tokenize("Hello there. Nice to meet you.")
['Hello', 'there.', 'Nice', 'to', 'meet', 'you', '.']
uses a metaphor for distance
anybody know nltk?  why would periods not get split out (first period in example above).
WordNet models how words are related to each other in sentences: http://wordnet.princeton.edu/
hack for getting clean text of a webpage:  lynx –dump [url]
SciPy: http://docs.scipy.org/doc/scipy/reference/spatial.html
using pycluster and numpy

K-means
1. Decide on number of clusters
2. Randomly place centroids
3. Iterate until clusters are formed
4. Iterate until convergence
answer to my own question above from the nltk docs: "This tokenizer should be fed a single sentence at a time"
download pycluster from here: http://bonsai.hgc.jp/~mdehoon/software/cluster/software.htm#pycluster
hcluster: http://code.google.com/p/scipy-cluster/
Stanford’s Free Classes on AI, Machine Learning, and Databases.... http://active.tutsplus.com/articles/news/stanford%E2%80%99s-free-classes-on-ai-machine-learning-and-databases/

Here are some other resources she mentioned:

* Book: Programming Collective Intelligence by Toby Segaran (O'Reilly)
* Book: Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning by Christopher Bishop
* Book: Machine Learning by Tom Mitchell
* Blog: Dataists: http://dataists.com/

Also found earlier in my notes, some places for data:

* Book: Data Source Handbook by Pete Warden (O'Reilly, http://oreilly.com/catalog/0636920018254)
* Hilary's bundle of research-quality data sets: http://bit.ly/f2cX4h
